page.title: 05HOUSING PATTERNS GT. EASTON
page.content: Most of the 16th C.lath and plaster houses in Great Easton are clustered together near the church.The first expansion in the village was when the Maynard estate was built.These are three pairs of red brick cottages built 1840-1860 and one larger house. In the 1950's when farmers were building large dutch barns,it became fashionable to buy up the old barns and convert them into houses.Bridge Foot Barn is an example of this.Others bought small cottages to convert into one larger house. The newest houses are built with breeze blocks and bricks.There is one new estate which is a cul-de-sac. Other new houses are built between the older houses.Next to the Bell is a house which is only 10 years old built in the old style to match the other houses nearby.
